report_title: Frozen Food Production in the US
executive_summary: Frozen food producers have expanded through the end of 2024 as boosting disposable income has allowed consumers to trade up to newer, healthier and premium varieties of goods that command higher retail prices. With more money to spend, some consumers have opted for fresh produce over frozen varieties, stifling expansion. Mounting health concerns have also led some consumers to purchase fewer frozen foods, which are often perceived as less healthy than fresher meals, despite new studies indicating otherwise. Frozen food producers have responded by introducing products with healthier, more nutritious ingredients.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Heightened Popularity for Healthy, Premium Products Has Somewhat Threatened Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Americans have become more health-conscious in recent years, evidenced by a contraction in per capita sugar and sweetener consumption, used as a proxy for health consciousness. Consumers have also become expansively aware of the high sodium content of some frozen prepared meals, weakening demand for these products through the end of 2024. This trend has been more significant for the frozen pizza segment, within which the inherently starchy and high-sodium nature of frozen pizza has challenged frozen food producers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Frozen Food Producers Have Found Ways to Remain Competitive
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Large frozen food producers have acquired many smaller producers, leading to some consolidation, which is largely the result of frozen food producers' desire to gain market share and expand product portfolios. Several smaller frozen food producers have entered the industry by offering niche products, including gluten-free, certified organic or fair-trade options, that are normally not offered by larger frozen food producers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Niche operators, like Amy's Kitchen and Kashi, have expanded considerably
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Niche operators, like Amy's Kitchen and Kashi, have expanded considerably as demand for organic frozen vegetables and specialty entrees has swelled. Amy's Kitchen produces organic, non-GMO frozen meals, soups and burgers, catering to vegan consumers and those with dietary needs like gluten-free. Meanwhile, Kashi is committed to making plant-based, whole grain and non-GMO foods.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Imported Frozen Foods Are Attractive to US Consumers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The value of frozen food imports has surged through the end of 2024, partly attributable to the expanding popularity of ethnic cuisines. Frozen food offerings in this category include mandarin chicken, samosas, enchiladas, pad Thai and sushi from various regions worldwide, allowing consumers to explore diverse cuisine without leaving their homes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Millennials Have Been Pivotal in Modifying Consumer Choices
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While the preference for fresh and organic foods soars with the boost in consumer discretionary income levels, it seems this trend has dropped off in recent years. Despite strengthened earnings in recent times, there's been a significant swell in the purchase of frozen foods among different generations like millennials and baby boomers. Convenience was a major factor in this shift, but many customers also emphasized perceived health benefits.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Frozen Food Producers Will Continue to Adapt to Everchanging Food Consumption Trends
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The convenience and affordability of frozen prepared meals will continue to attract customers. With today's fast-paced lifestyle, many individuals often lack the time to prepare meals from scratch. Frozen meals come pre-cooked and only require reheating, substantially reducing preparation time. Plus, they can also be stored for extended periods. Expanding health consciousness will continue to benefit frozen fruit and vegetable producers, as new research demonstrates that freezing foods preserve certain nutrients better than refrigeration or canning.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Heightened External Competition Will Force Frozen Food Producers to Find Creative Ways to Remain Competitive
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Technological developments in freezing, packaging and sorting, combined with aggressive marketing for new products, will be imperative for frozen food producers. Expanding marketing, in addition to distribution efforts abroad, will also boost exports.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Boosting Input Prices Will Pressure Frozen Food Producers to Push Up Prices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Vegetable and fruit prices will strengthen as these types of food expand in popularity alongside boosted health concerns among consumers. The prices of primary ingredients in frozen foods are essential. With the worsening impacts of climate change expected to impact crop yields, the outlook for primary ingredients used in frozen foods is becoming increasingly uncertain. The potential for reduced crop yields due to extreme weather events, changes in temperature patterns and water scarcity could lead to price volatility for inputs of frozen food production.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Enhanced Technology May Help Boost Demand From Downstream Markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Fast food chains, known for their substantial consumption of frozen products, will likely make more frozen food orders. This boost will include items like frozen potatoes and breakfast meals. In response to consumers' increasing health consciousness, the fast food industry will likely expand healthier options, providing an opportunity for fast food producers that offer such options.

industry_definition: Frozen food producers manufacture frozen packaged foods, which include frozen fruits, vegetables and juices; frozen packaged meals and side dishes (excluding unprocessed seafood); frozen pizza; frozen whipped toppings; and frozen breakfast and baked goods, including waffles and pancakes. These products are then distributed to retail grocery stores, food wholesalers and the hospitality industry.
key_trends: Competition among frozen food producers is chiefly based on product price, quality and differentiation.
A frozen food producer's relationship with upstream and downstream markets is also important because these relationships can determine input costs or the price producers charge downstream customers.

Frozen food producers endure stiff competition from fast food restaurants and retail channels that offer prepared food. While frozen meals offer consumers convenience and good taste at a low cost, fast food and prepared meals also offer these qualities and can be more convenient than frozen meals.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Grocery wholesalers supply supermarkets, convenience stores, other retail channels and food service operators with large volumes of frozen food products for resale or use. This market is the most crucial retail link in the supply chain because frozen food producers' relationships with wholesalers largely influence the products that retailers and food service customers eventually stock.

Within the retail segment, operations include direct shipments from manufacturers to large supermarket chains, grocery stores and convenience stores. These shipments are a crucial part of the supply chain. While only supermarkets with sufficient purchasing power have historically bought goods directly from manufacturers, boosting wholesale bypass has allowed smaller-scale retailers to sidestep wholesalers and purchase directly from producers.
Frozen food is in high demand at restaurants, hotels, schools, hospitals and other catering institutions, making them the second-largest market for this type of product.

products_and_services.product_description: This broad segment includes a variety of meat and specialty selections (not including frozen pizza selections) that can be prepared on the stove, in the oven or in the microwave.

This product segment includes a variety of nutritious frozen veggies like peas, corn, butternut squash, edamame, okra, cauliflower rice, broccoli, artichoke hearts and many other vegetables, ready to cook and enjoy.

This segment encompasses a variety of frozen pizzas, including cheese-only and ones with numerous toppings, ranging from vegetables to pepperoni and much more. Also included in this segment are gluten- and grain-free frozen pizza options.

This market segment includes a vast array of frozen fruit and juice concentrates in flavors like orange, apple, grapefruit, cranberry, grape and limeade, providing customers with a wide choice of refreshing tastes.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: With the expansion of per capita disposable income, consumers could gain purchasing power to buy more frozen foods, even premium ones.

E-commerce sales are a measure of retail sales conducted online in the US. Major e-commerce players like Amazon.com Inc., Walmart Inc. and Target Corporation offer additional convenience to consumers.
If consumers choose healthier diets with lower carb and higher protein intake, then they are likely to consume less grains and more meat.

Vegetables represent a crucial ingredient for frozen meals. It's also a large product segment for frozen food producers. When the price of fresh vegetables swells, more consumers purchase frozen ones, which aren't as costly.
The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its trading partners.
Domestic trips by US residents measure the number of business and recreational trips happening in any given year in the US.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) Influences Import Concentration
international_trade_points.trade_description: Most imports come from Canada and Mexico since the USMCA established with the United States pushes down trade barriers and makes trade easier among these countries.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Consumer Desire for Variety Encourages Import Penetration
international_trade_points.trade_description: Countries including Canada, Mexico, Brazil and Belgium will continue to be popular sources of imports because of an expanding demand for ethnic dishes and frozen tropical fruit varieties.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Canada and Mexico Are Major Export Hubs for Domestically Produced Frozen Foods
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada continues to be a leading destination for United States frozen foods, largely because of its advantageous geographic location and mutually beneficial trade agreements that simplify commerce.

Consumers in Mexico have tastes and preferences similar to those of US consumers. Mexico has grown substantially as an export market over the past five years in particular, likely due to the institution of the USMCA.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Japanese Consumers Also Desire Frozen Foods Manufactured in the United States
international_trade_points.trade_description: Fresh produce in Japan is relatively expensive and the expanding price of fresh fruits and vegetables has led many Japanese consumers to demand less costly alternatives at grocery stores.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The frozen food industry is mature.
Frozen food producers must obtain necessary licenses and provide proper labeling and disclose ingredients.
New entrants aiming to compete with mid-to-large companies need to invest heavily in production equipment and machinery.
Smaller producers focus on providing premium foods with non-GMO, organic or fair-trade ingredients rather than competing on price and distribution.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition among frozen food producers is chiefly based on product price, quality and differentiation.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Conagra Brands and Schwan Company maintain strong positions due to their recognizable brands, production scale and established distribution networks, dominating the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large Manufacturers Seek Expansion Through Acquisitions
concentration_points.concentration_description: Top producers have acquired smaller companies to enter niche markets, expand product varieties and attract health-conscious consumers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Input Volatility Equates to Uncertain Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Prices of key production inputs have endured fluctuations through the end of 2024.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Producers are expanding purchases of gluten- and grain-free ingredients
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Producers are expanding purchases of gluten- and grain-free ingredients, like nut and seed flours.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Packaging materials constitute a substantial portion of purchases
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Packaging materials constitute a substantial portion of purchases since producers use plastic, cardboard, paper and other products to package finished goods.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While most frozen food producers rely on manual labor to operate machinery, larger producers have adequate funding to invest in labor-saving machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Everchanging Consumer Preferences Constantly Challenge Frozen Food Produce
volatility_points.volatility_description: While frozen foods are popular for the time-poor consumer, they aren't integral to a healthy diet.
In response to concerns regarding the nutritional value of certain products, frozen food producers have developed products with healthier, more nutritious ingredients.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Input Price Volatility Promotes Revenue Swings
volatility_points.volatility_description: Cost fluctuations of food inputs influence selling prices and revenue direction trends.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Frozen Food Producers Were Forced to Navigate Volatility Amid COVID-19
volatility_points.volatility_description: The pandemic caused a surge in demand for frozen pizzas as consumers sought convenient meal options during lockdowns.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Frozen Food Producers Have Implemented Numerous Techniques to Help Slow the Rate at Which Foods Spoil
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Blanching is a popular method predominantly used for processing fruit and vegetable products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Flash freezing is a highly effective method for preserving various types of food
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Flash freezing is a highly effective method for preserving various types of food.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Innovative Isochoric Freezing Technique Improves Frozen Food Quality
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Isochoric freezing offers an advantage over traditional freezing methods.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by expanding imports?
FAQs.answer: Similar to many manufacturing industries, the Frozen Food Production industry is hurt by imports as it boosts competition in US markets.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Larger frozen food producers typically produce a wide array of products.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices?
FAQs.answer: Profit fluctuates with changes in the cost of inputs, like the price of vegetables.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Larger frozen food producers continue to invest heavily in research and development to meet changing consumer preferences.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Larger frozen food producers invest heavily in research and development.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Automation technology replaces repetitive manual labor with machines.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profit recently?
FAQs.answer: Frozen food producers are primarily regulated by federal agencies.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Frozen food producers frequently work with trade associations.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Customers paying on time is not a significant threat to frozen food producers.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Larger frozen food producers typically have larger profit because of their ability to benefit from economies of scale.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? How do you guard against fluctuations in input prices?
FAQs.answer: Frozen food producers generally have reliable contracts with suppliers.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor changing consumer preferences? How quickly can you release new products to cater to recent health trends?
FAQs.answer: Frozen food producers must be able to anticipate and respond promptly to changes in consumer preferences.

FAQs.question: How do you respond to variability in consumer demand? How can you diversify your product mix?
FAQs.answer: Successful frozen food producers can differentiate their products and brands.

FAQs.question: How has a contraction in time spent on leisure and sports impacted your company over recent years? How do you appeal to time-strapped consumers?
FAQs.answer: One of the significant benefits of frozen prepared meals is convenience over fresher food alternatives.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor changes in the trade-weighted index? How much of your revenue comes from international markets?
FAQs.answer: Exports, sensitive to exchange rate fluctuations, are a vital growth factor for frozen food producers.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor changes in per capita disposable income? Can you boost your prices to reflect higher per capita disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Higher per capita disposable income allows consumers to purchase more frozen food products.
